name: National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics
theoryOfChange: By uniting, supporting, and training Muslim charitable clinics, the association enhances their capability to provide high-quality care and expand services to underserved populations.
zakatClaimEvidence: No explicit mention of zakat donations found for the National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics in the provided search results. The search results describe NAMCC as a non-profit, 501(c)(3) organization that unites healthcare organizations and clinics, and mentions fundraising sources and grant opportunities, but does not specifically state that they accept zakat. (Source: https://naomcc.org/Donations)

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Limited match due to weaker results and/or higher uncertainty; review methodology details before deciding.

all_citations.claim: The organization is identified as a network for healthcare organizations with limited financial data available.
Financial data including total revenue and program expense ratios are not currently reported in available filings.
The organization accepts donations to support its mission of aiding member clinics and healthcare initiatives.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization receives a score of 32/100 due to significant gaps in available financial data and a lack of third-party verification of its impact. While it addresses an urgent global health cause, the low data confidence reflects a need for greater transparency.

Lack of comprehensive financial reporting and independent ratings

dimension_explanations.alignment: The alignment score of 23/50 reflects a moderate fit; while the organization addresses the urgent cause of global health, there is limited evidence of specific features that cater to the preferences of Muslim donors [1]. Contributions are accepted as general charitable giving or sadaqah [3].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization's impact score of 14/50 is limited by a lack of cost-per-beneficiary data and evidence of direct effectiveness [1]. Its primary role is capacity building for other clinics, but specific metrics regarding these programs are currently unavailable in public filings [2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics serves as a unifying network for healthcare organizations to enhance community wellness through collaborative support.
strengths: Facilitates collaboration between diverse healthcare providers
Provides a centralized platform for member organization support
baseline_narrative.summary: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics (NAOMCC) functions as a representative body that unites various healthcare organizations to streamline medical services [1]. The organization focuses on providing essential support for its member clinics to improve operational capacity and outreach [3].

strengths.detail: The organization <cite id="4">meets all 20 Standards</cite> of the BBB Wise Giving Alliance, demonstrating a baseline commitment to ethical practices.
NAOMCC effectively <cite id="3">unites various healthcare organizations</cite> to pool resources and share best practices across the sector.
The charity maintains <cite id="4">audited financial statements</cite>, providing a layer of financial verification despite limited public data.

strengths_deep_dive: NAOMCC's primary value proposition lies in its capacity-building model. By focusing on <cite id="3">collaboration and resource pooling</cite>, the organization amplifies the impact of individual charitable clinics. This network approach allows for centralized <cite id="3">education and training</cite> programs that elevate the standard of care across multiple member organizations. Furthermore, the charity's adherence to rigorous accountability frameworks is evidenced by the fact that it <cite id="4">meets all 20 Standards</cite> from the BBB Wise Giving Alliance, which includes maintaining a <cite id="4">conflict of interest policy</cite> and undergoing independent financial audits.
rich_narrative.summary: The National Association of Muslim Charitable Clinics (NAOMCC) serves as a unifying network for healthcare organizations, focusing on enhancing community wellness through collaborative support. Operating primarily within the <cite id="3">USA</cite>, the organization functions as a representative body that <cite id="3">unites various healthcare organizations</cite> to streamline medical services and improve operational capacity. As a capacity-building entity, NAOMCC provides <cite id="3">support for member organizations</cite>, facilitating <cite id="3">education and training</cite> alongside <cite id="3">advocacy efforts</cite> to strengthen the infrastructure of Muslim-led healthcare initiatives. While the organization is an emerging entity with a <cite id="1">developing theory of change</cite>, it has demonstrated a commitment to accountability by ensuring it <cite id="4">meets all 20 Standards</cite> set by the BBB Wise Giving Alliance, including maintaining <cite id="4">audited financial statements</cite>. However, donors should be aware that the organization currently has <cite id="1">limited data availability</cite>, resulting in a low data confidence score. The charity operates with a <cite id="2">small board of 2 members</cite>, which presents governance limitations. For donors seeking to support healthcare infrastructure, NAOMCC offers a <cite id="3">sadaqah-eligible</cite> avenue to invest in the long-term capacity of charitable clinics, though it lacks the comprehensive financial reporting and independent impact evaluations typical of more established institutions.
